review: I've had my Roku for about a month now.  I bought it so I can "cut the cord" and get rid of cable, though I haven't done it yet.  If your plan is to drop cable, it is a good option; I figure I will get about 80-90% of the programming I want for about 30% of the monthly cost (Netflix, Hulu and Amazon Prime give me almost everything I want to watch, buying the handful of cable shows I watch that I can't get free on these services will get me most of the rest).  If you want to buy it to supplement cable or FIOS, it makes your online streaming programming so easy to use that it is more than worth the cost.I have been happy with the ease of use.  The remote interface is easy and very intuitive to use.  I have the Streaming Stick in my bedroom, and I got the Roku 3 for my living room TV later because I liked the Stick so much (I had been leaning towards getting the Amazon Fire TV, but my experience with the Roku stick changed my mind).  Both the Stick and Roku 3 are quite small and unobtrusive, though, the stick is just so much more compact since it plugs into your HDMI slot, you plug in the power cord, and it takes absolutely no space on your TV stand.Picture is good, sound is good, not much to say there.  No complaints about streaming speed, it works as well as my cable (maybe better since I often have my cable temporarily die out on me).  The only complaint is Netflix loads up fairly slowly, but since it is the only app which is so slow I think that has more to do with Netflix than Roku.I love it so much, and it is user friendly enough, that I will be buying one for my 70 year old father for Chanukah along with a Major League Baseball TV subscription so he can use his Amazon Prime subscription on TV and also see all of the Pirates games next season.I will update this review in a few months after I've had the Roku devices longer (and I did pre-order the Amazon Fire TV Stick when it was available for $19 for Amazon Prime members so I will also be able to do a comparison then).
